newsitem.title: USA: U.S. average retail beef prices rise in month - NCBA.
newsitem.headline: U.S. average retail beef prices rise in month - NCBA.

text.p: Average retail beef prices rose during the past month, the National Cattlemen's Beef Association (NCBA) said in a report.

The NCBA, summarizing its regular monthly 19-city survey of supermarkets, said the average price of six cuts of beef on October 10 was $3.02 per lb., compared with $2.97 on September 12 and $3.00 a year ago.

It said beef production continued to decrease and cattle and wholesale beef prices rose to their highest level in a year. Meanwhile retail featuring of beef decreased somewhat but remained widespread, the NCBA said.
The NCBA six-cut average on Oct 10 was up from a month earlier in only seven cities but the increases were large enough to raise the overall average slightly.

The 19-city averages for the six cuts on Oct 10 were as follows: regular ground beef, $1.41 per pound; lean ground beef, $1.87; boneless round steak, $3.05; boneless top sirloin steak, $3.79; T-bone steak, $5.74; and boneless chuck roll roast $2.29.
